segments.text: I inferred from your work on disarmament and so forth that you would have been in effect opposed to international cooperation in terms of weapon systems and so forth.
Well, what I'm opposed to is wars.
And what I'm interested in is the reduction of the chance of war.
Now clearly, if you take the two extremes,
If the United States became extremely aggressive, started to build up arguments on, say, twice the present scale, this would be destabilizing.
It would force the opposition to do the same thing and might well precipitate a preemptive war.
I mean, it is not safe in the modern world to have an extremely aggressive policy.
On the other hand, it's quite unsafe to disarm.
I mean, obviously, if the Russians
The government wouldn't last six months.
They get themselves blown up.
And country-wise, so there must be some policy in between which is optimum from this point of view.
And my own view is that the present levels of force are set by a competition with the Russians.
We have to have as many tanks as the Russians, as many ballistic missiles as the Russians, and so on.
And that the levels are excessive.
that the present levels are more than is required for deterrence, and that this is dangerous, that we're erring on the top side.
But the only way of reducing it is to reduce by agreement.
And there are very strong reasons, I think, for reaching agreements to reduce mutually.
The difficulties, of course, are verification and so on, but the
Deterrence is so much in excess of any conceivable requirement that I think a moderate degree of cheating would not really do you any harm.
I mean, we would be no better off if the Russians had their present level of ballistic missiles and we had twice as many.
We'd be no safer at all, not the least.

Because already there are sufficient missiles on both sides to ensure the complete destruction of the other society, plus a considerable margin over for dealing with third parties who might intervene.
And the thing is, the damage that will be done is so out of proportion of the object in view that I think
anyone who has any knowledge, I don't know anyone who has any knowledge of this matter, who doesn't think that the levels ought to be reduced, and they can only be reduced by negotiation.

And even the Verdi-Vostok Agreement I was in favour of, because it sets a level, it sets levels rather above the present levels, which are ludicrously high for any requirement, but you can at least, at least then becomes, if you have an agreement, it becomes a numerical map.
And on the whole, Congress is not very interested in numbers.
I mean, they don't know the difference between 3,000 warheads and 100 warheads.
I once tried an experiment on this.
I was in a meeting, I think I was chairman of the meeting, discussing what was a level of effective deterrence from the point of view of England.
And this was a fairly technical discussion of the defence book.
And we were talking about this, and the Foreign Office had asked whether they could just come in and listen.
We said we didn't want to discuss the questions of what was politically acceptable, we just wanted to discuss the technical question.
I mean, like reliability of missiles, number reaching the target, all this kind of amount of damage done, all this kind of thing.
And I said, towards the end of the meeting, I said, look, we've got the Foreign Office here.
They're the people who will, in effect, make the decision to use these things or not to use them.
I'd like to ask them a very simple question.
I said, suppose that there is a 50% chance of one megaton landing on Piccadilly Circus, and this is a risk you might have to take.
For what would you take this risk?
What desirable things are there in the world for which you would take a 50% risk of one megaton on Piccadilly Circus?
The foreigners' reaction was very interesting.
They had no notice of this question.
They just looked poor.
there's no such thing.
There's nothing.
I said, not the Middle East oil?
He said, no, of course not.
Not the control of the Indian Ocean?
No, nothing.
And it was quite clear that for him, effective deterrence was somewhere below a 50% chance of one megaton on Piccadilly Circus.
Well, there you are, you see.
That, in fact,
In the real world, people will not deliberately plan a war if there are high probabilities of the major towns being destroyed.

So that the levels are excessive and the present levels are defended on grounds that it might be possible for the other side, if they had a sufficient preponderance, to destroy all our weapons before they fire.
This is not really numerically plausible.
I mean, how many... After all, three or four weapons left will destroy the major cities of the other side.
And how many shots have you got to have at each ballistic missile silo or each submarine to ensure a high probability that all but one or two were destroyed?
Well, it's not all.
So I think no one... With much lower levels of deterrence than we have now,
No one would rationally start a war.
And on the whole, the chances of accidentally starting a war are increased with the level of forces.
So from the accidental war point of view, it pays you to reduce them.
From the deliberate war point of view, I think, it also pays you to reduce them.
Because if anyone had a war, it would do less damage.
And the deterrence is just as good.
So I think I'm perfectly consistent.
I'm interested in disarmament.
I'm interested in disarmament.
not for emotional reasons, but to reduce the chance and the consequences of nuclear war.
And I don't think disarmament to zero is necessarily the optimum.
The most important thing, I think, at the moment is to decrease the effectiveness of the tank.
You see, there is a risk of the Russians feeling that attack on Russia and on America is completely deterred.
And therefore, they could safely drive their tanks across Europe.

And it's well known that a few years ago, there was a detailed analysis of this by well informed people, which was leaked to Der Spiegel, I think, and published, which arrived at the conclusion that the Russians could not be held for a week before they reached the Rhine.
Well now, if they tried that, it is an extremely dangerous situation, because beyond doubt,
We would use tactical nuclear weapons after about day two.
Now, there isn't in fact such a thing as a tactical nuclear weapon.
There's really no distinction.
And we would certainly use so-called tactical nuclear weapons to destroy bridges back in Poland.
And very soon we'd be using them to destroy tank factories.
And the thing would escalate, I think, in spite of the deterrence.
I think it's a great danger of such an enterprise escalating.

And so I think the important things at the moment are to... Well, I can't talk about what has actually happened, what the present situation is, but the situation in which the tank was a very effective weapon, which certainly existed five or ten years ago, is a very dangerous situation.
And I don't know, or at least I don't know what the situation is at the moment.
Come in.
After the tape's off, I'll make a comment on that, by the way.
My comments are not important.
What about the risk in building nuclear energy plants, for example, if you don't... Well, I mean, clearly, this is a very important question indeed.
I mean, it's not a negligible question.
I think
The difficulty in public discussion of this is quite a general one.
It is this, that if in a certain activity you have a risk, now what arguments do you use for taking or not taking this risk?
The trouble with the Sierra Club and the ecological lobby generally is that they argue that if we do this,
There will be disadvantages, certain adverse things, undesirable things, which will certainly happen.
There will also be risks of catastrophes of one sort and another.
Therefore, we should not do this.
Therefore, we oppose this.
The trouble with this line of argument is that it can be used against all alternative causes of action.
So you're left with no causes of action.
They may be different groups that oppose the different ones, or they may be the same one.
Now, in fact, I think it is true that all human actions have both advantages and disadvantages and have risks associated with them.
And the problem of decision is to make your decision so as...
In some sense, to maximize the advantages, minimize the disadvantages, and in particular, to minimize catastrophes.
But you are going to reduce these things to zero.
I think the ecological lobby generally is not living in the real world.
That's to say, they assume that you can have certainty in human affairs.
I was talking about this recently in Santa Barbara.
And I was talking about bouncing one thing against another and so on, and someone got up and asked, but what is your long-term policy?
It's not tolerable to go on like this.
And I said, well, actually, you know, life is riding a bicycle on a tightrope.
It's not driving a tricycle on a road.
That's to say...
You keep your equilibrium and keep things going, not by the nature of the system, but by continual adjustments.
It's an interaction between what happens and the thing you're doing, which is important.
And I think the people who argue against any sort of technological developments feel that they ought to be riding a tricycle.
That the things they're doing ought to have the automatic safety from
from tipping over of the third wheel.
You shouldn't have to avoid catastrophes by continual adjustment.

But I think the nature of the world and the nature of society is that, in fact, it is a cybernetic system in which you have to adjust the progress as you go along in order to steer yourself between the different kinds of disasters.
And, well, now, if you apply this to nuclear power stations, obviously, you can, nuclear power stations are dangerous.
If a nuclear power station falls to pieces, large amounts of radioactivity will be emitted, and there will be a catastrophe.
A meaning by catastrophe is something in which more than a few hundred people are killed.
I mean, a thing in which a hundred people are killed is not a catastrophe.
Catastrophe is a thing that society doesn't want to accept.
I mean, they'll accept accidents to jumbo jets.
I landed in New York in the middle of a lot of fire engines the other day because a jumbo jet had lost one engine.
Well, society accepts this kind of thing, but they'll accept very large numbers of deaths which are not obvious.
They will, for instance, accept in the last of the big London fogs, the deaths from respiratory disease
by 2,000 over this short period.
So in a sense, the London Fog killed 2,000 people, which can't identify the people.
And many of them would probably have died anyway in the succeeding weeks.
So no one worried much.
But the fogs were so unpleasant, and particularly this last one was so unpleasant, that they did, in fact, do something about it.
And they have now got rid of the London Fogs by control of the burning of coal.
Well, the
For easily understandable historical reasons, the danger of accidents to nuclear plants, even quite remote ones, are unacceptable at the moment.
But people are not considering the alternative dangers.
And, of course, one can argue empirically.
There have been a lot of nuclear power stations banned, particularly in England has been getting
something like 10 or 15% of its power from nuclear fuel for a good many years.
And in this country, there are all the weapons reactors.
Been here for 30 years or so.
And no one has yet been killed by them, as far as one knows.
There have been accidents.
The most serious accident, I suppose, was the Canadian accident at Chalk River just after the war.
There were some cows who started giving radioactive milk after an accident in England and the milk had to be poured down the drain and there was a great scene about this.
There have been minor accidents which are a warning that if you don't take the proper precautions there may be more serious accidents.
But I think the alternatives seem to me less desirable.
quite disturbed about the big coal power plants in Utah, which are in the middle of some of the finest scenery in the United States.
And I don't know in detail about them, but is it really acceptable to have all this smoke and stuff on the outside in the air over southern Utah?
The inhabitants of Utah don't mind because they don't live there.
And the inhabitants of California, I think, do mind to some extent because this is one of their holiday areas.
The obvious thing to do is to put the coal power stations in Mexico.
Yeah.
But you can't say this.
Well, so my feeling is that the risks of operation of nuclear power stations can be contained.
It's important, of course, not to have the AC or whatever it's called now, both judge and jury.
That I think there must be a regulatory agency who isn't responsible actually for running them as well.
that you can avoid having accidents with nuclear power stations with a frequency which matters to anyone.
I mean, once you get up to one accident in 100,000 years, well, I don't much mind if it occurs.
I mean, it's a negligible thing.
It's, you know, a tenth of a person per year or something of this sort.
Of course, every human activity kills people.
I mean, people fall off scaffolding.
And building buildings is extremely dangerous.
I mean, building nuclear power stations is much more dangerous than operating them.
I think more people are likely to be killed by falling off the scaffolding than by escape of radioactivity.
The one that does worry me is the disposal of waste.
And I'm about to attempt to write a report on this.
I haven't got around to it at all yet.
But it looks as if someone's going to pay me for writing a report on it.
I think it's a serious problem, but I suspect not an insoluble one.
I don't really know enough about it at this point to give an opinion.
It might turn out that it's really very undesirable and is fatal to the nuclear power program, but I imagine that satisfactory solutions can be found.
I mean, what I want to do is to read up on the whole subject.
Sir, I have a question.
I'd like to interject a personal question, if I may.
Are you, as a scientist, offended by comments of other people, like the oceans are dying, for example, or soon the Red Sea will be gone?
I'm irritated by them because of the...
I don't believe that in order to support what you emotionally believe to be a good cause, you should tell what you know to be lies.
And clearly, Mr. Nader, and I won't say Mr. Nader, I'm not going to say anyone personally, but there clearly are people around, I specifically exclude Mr. Nader, there are people around who
are telling lies which they know to be lies, and there are a great many others who are telling lies which they haven't taken the trouble to find that they're lies.

Okay, now the point of this question is, is when a man of your eminence and ability writes a report on nuclear waste, and suppose the report suggests that nuclear waste disposal with a minimum risk is possible, shouldn't there not be some way for scientists to publicize this to the general public?
Well, there's a great deal of, I mean, there is a great deal of publicity
on this subject.
I mean, if I should write a report to the people who are paying me, their interest is, their ultimate interest is, is there a field in which they could make a useful contribution?
I mean, can we, we're trying to think of a program of work on disposal of nuclear waste which is useful and which, of course, can be paid for.
And one of the things we are starting to do
is simply to write as objective a report as possible on what the risks are in the different possible schemes.
I mean, it involves things like, are the extrapolations in the number of nuclear power stations in any sense realistic?
I mean, the trouble is that many of the projections in the nuclear power industry involve such a very rapid increase.
that you are allowed to get into trouble because there is a limit to the rate at which you can safely grow.
Because you see, as I say, the thing is a steering problem of adjusting yourself as you go along.
If you're a crash programmer, you're extremely allowed to get yourself in a dangerous situation before you notice it.
I mean, there is a certain deliberate haste, as I think the political phase usually is, is desirable.
You mustn't go madly into things which may

actually prove dangerous you've got to go into them rather slowly and see what happens it's like the question of the ozone you see as far as i know no one really knows what anything you do will do to the ozone layer i mean will the present production of these spray compounds do anything to the ozone layer well i don't think anyone could put their hand on their hearts and say they were certain
But what is certain is that the effect is quite slow.
Because after all, we've been using these bloody cans for years and years and years, and not much has happened.
And the ozone layer fluctuates 50% anyway.
And what you've got to do is to monitor it and keep an eye on it.
And at some point, you may decide certain things are dangerous.
But you don't need, just because there's a possibility of something wrong, to go into a lot of legislation and a lot of inconvenience very rapidly.
But this is because the use of these things is not going to increase enormously rapidly.
If we were going to have 10 times as many used every year, then clearly it would be dangerous.
But if you're going along at about the present level, slowly increasing, you'll keep an eye on it.
So I think there's a great deal to be said in these dangerous situations of deliberate haste.
Let's say making haste rather slowly.
Now, I have one more question.
Looking back and reading about your career,
You almost typify, well, you excel actually, in the kind of scientist who's able to mix together academic, military, and business worlds.
Was this deliberate in your career?
I've always had this feeling on the one side that what I like doing is science and what I ought to do is science.
And then I become interested in other things and I've gone off and
and done them, and finally I began to realize that I had the two sides to my character.
I like doing both.
And in fact, I've leant away from science in the latter part of my career.
I haven't really done much science for the last ten years.
I mean, I've had a very good group in Cambridge, and I've encouraged them, and I've spent a lot of time talking to them.
But personally, I haven't done much.
I mean, what I can do still
is talk to people and suggest what they would do.
But I usually decide it's really too much of a business to do it myself.
And I think also science is to some extent a young man's game.
I mean, I've not got the originality and the power of going out and starting new things now as I get older.
I mean, after all, I feel I'm going to die before long.
There's no good starting very long-term projects.
I mean, like when I started investigating the floor of the ocean, it would be silly to do something, start something like that again at my age, you see.
I think it's partly, this is partly, you know, a background and class thing.
I know it's a very unfashionable thing to say, but I think you come from a well-off background where there's not been a tremendous struggle.
then you easily get a self-confidence and a feeling you can do things, feeling you're the man who knows about it and ought to make good choices.
And you can, in fact, chase around people from other backgrounds and get what you want.
I mean, like these poor chaps who were in charge of demagnetizing ships during the war, and they just didn't know what had hit them.
They were out before they knew what was happening.
They didn't know any of the right people
They didn't know how to behave.
They wouldn't behave as badly as I was willing to behave.
I mean, I've at various times been willing to behave pretty badly.
And a certain feeling about the value of money, an objective feeling about money.
You see, people ordinarily have a realistic feeling about sums of money they normally spend themselves.
Parkinson pointed out.
that you will always, on a board of directors, get a vigorous discussion about building a bicycle shed.
But if you have a discussion about building a nuclear-powered aircraft, no one will know anything about it, and you'll get hardly any discussion at all.
And this is very true, that people have got realistic ideas about money they've been used to hearing talked about.
I mean, if you've always known fairly rich people, and if you've always moved in
Circles where people are directors of companies and high officials and governments and so on.
You're used to talking about large sums of money.
And so that you start with an advantage against people brought up in different backgrounds.
This sounds rather unfair and extremely unfashionable.
And of course it's clearly extremely inequitable, but that's how things work.
